newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil soybean crush higher this year to July.
newsitem.headline: Brazil soybean crush higher this year to July.

text.p: Brazil's soybean crush reached some 11.6 million tonnes of soybeans in February-July 1996, up from 11.36 million tonnes crushed in the same 1995 period, said Brazilian Vegetable Oils Association Abiove.
The higher crush comes despite a smaller harvest this year and has been encouraged by this year's higher exports of soybeans and soymeal, the association indicated.

"While Abiove's figures formally registered a crush of 10.45 million tonnes in February-July 1996, the information received so far is incomplete and the actual figure should be at least ten percent higher," Abiove secretary Fabio Trigueirinho said.
As from the month of August, soybean crushings slow down considerably, Trigueirinho said.
Brazil's final soybean stocks stood at 4.98 million tonnes on July 31, 1996, down from 5.61 million tonnes on July 31, 1995, Abiove said.
Final stocks of soymeal stood at 984,000 tonnes on July 31, 1996, down from 996,000 tonnes a year previously.
Final stocks of soyoil were however higher this year at 391,000 tonnes, up from 295,000 tonnes on July 31, 1995, the association said.
State export department Secex figures meanwhile show Brazil exported 2.82 million tonnes of soybeans in February-July 1996, up from 2.73 million in the same 1995 period.
Exports of soymeal also grew in February-July this year to 6.43 million tonnes, from 5.69 million in the 1995 period.
Brazil's soyoil exports however fell to 772,000 tonnes in February-July 1996 from 819,000 tonnes in the same 1995 period, according to Secex.
-- Diana Kinch, Rio de Janeiro newsroom, 5521 5074151
